bibl.title: Letter from Laura Wood to Philip Showalter Hench, March 16, 1942

div1.p: Wood thanks Hench for comments on her manuscript - responding to some of them - and discusses her work. She used Ashburn's history of the Army Medical Corps for some statistics. Wood insists that Hench write his book on Reed because she feels it will be definitive.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Wood to Philip Showalter Hench, March 16, 1942
div1.p:
Thanks so much for your nice and painstaking letter,
which I will answer in detail when I get back to
Washington. Now I have to get on the train for
Philadelphia in an hour or so.

First: after I broke my neck to get in by March
15 they decided to put it over to Fall. What keeps
me from being enraged is that it will give me a
chance to ans check a couple more things - like who
got sick during the fomites experiment (I don't know
now where I got the idea it was Cooke) - and give
Lazear more of a break. I hadn't known until I got
these photostats that it was Lazear who caught on
to Carter's tables and not Reed.

You absolutely must do your book on this - it will
be final and definitive and neither General Truby's
nor mine pretends to be - his is personal recollections
and mine is about Reed only and fictionalized a bit
as to conversations, etc. and neither covers the
ground that yours will.

It is amusing that some of my conversations sound
like Yellow Jack, because I didn't read it - only
the first couple of scenes, that is. It seemed so
lousy that i didn't bother to finish it since I al-
ready knew it was inaccurate.

It was meant to be 1600, not 1000 soldiers and I
used the rather poor expression stopped bullets be-
cause I couldn't find out whether that many had been
killed or killed and wounded, from the book I took
it out of - it was Ashburn'snhistory of the Army
Medical Corps. Those S-A War statistics are the
dickens, anyway - I couldn't make head or tail of
them and every book says something different. Neither
did I especially care. The $20, 000 for the MD to
spend came out of Ashburn, too.

The publisher shares your thought that it sounds a
bit adult for kids. Unfortunately, it begins like
a children's book, only somehow as the subject got
tougher the kiddies got older. Also, General Kean
says that Reed didn't tell him his suspicions about
Lazear.

I'm afraid I've been pretty remiss not to see George
Carroll - I heard about your adventures with him, and
they were noteencouraging, however, so maybe I won't
anyway.

Fitz Lee was rather a close friend of Kean's father,
but Gen. Kean says he didn't call him that, so that's
already changed. They knew each other in the Civil
War, I guess.
Now I have to go catch my train.

I'll see if I can piece together a whole copy to send
you, although I don't think I can right now - when the
artist gets through maybe I can get his back. I was
furious to see that he did the inside cover with an
underclad nifty kneeling in the street beside a prone
gent stricken presumably by yellow fever. I haven't
any control over the illustrations, which will be a
lesson to me if I ever do another book. However, they
are pretty good on the whole, what' I've seen.
Now I do have to go for the train.

I'm glad it was such a clean copy of Kelly - I didn't
think you were hinting.
